statement.text: Dialysis access for hemodialysis includes arteriovenous fistula (AVF), arteriovenous graft (AVG), and central venous catheters. The 'fistula first' approach prioritizes native AVF creation due to superior patency, lower infection rates, and reduced morbidity compared to grafts and catheters. Optimal access planning begins when GFR <30 mL/min/1.73mÂ².
statement.formal: Dialysis Access Hierarchy: AVF (native, preferred) > AVG (prosthetic) > Catheter (temporary/bridge); 'Fistula First': plan AVF when GFR <30

explanation.intuition: Hemodialysis requires accessing the blood at high flow rates (300-500 mL/min) three times weekly. Normal veins can't handle this - they're too small and fragile. A fistula surgically connects an artery to a vein, causing the vein to enlarge and thicken over several weeks ('maturation'), creating a durable access point. It's like upgrading a residential water line to an industrial one.
explanation.key_insight: AVF is superior to all other access types but requires 6-12 weeks to mature before use. This means planning ahead - referral for access creation when GFR drops below 30. The most distal, non-dominant arm fistula should be attempted first to preserve proximal sites for future access.
explanation.technical_details: AVF creation involves anastomosis of an artery to superficial vein. Common configurations: radiocephalic (Brescia-Cimino, most distal, preferred), brachiocephalic, brachiobasilic (two-stage with transposition). Maturation requires flow increase and wall thickening - 'Rule of 6s': 6mm diameter, 6mm depth, 600 mL/min flow, usable by 6 weeks.

avg.description: Prosthetic graft (PTFE) connecting artery to vein

preoperative_planning.referral_timing: When GFR <30 or expected dialysis within 6-12 months
preoperative_planning.vein_preservation: Avoid venipuncture and IV placement in non-dominant arm
preoperative_planning.vein_mapping: Duplex ultrasound to assess vein diameter (>2.5mm), depth, continuity

site_selection.order_preference: Non-dominant arm first; most distal site first
site_selection.radiocephalic: Wrist-level, preserves proximal sites, lowest flow (less steal)
site_selection.brachiocephalic: Antecubital, higher success rate, higher flow
site_selection.brachiobasilic: Requires transposition (basilic vein deep), good secondary option
site_selection.leg: Thigh AVF/AVG - when upper extremity exhausted

maturation.timeline: 6-12 weeks for AVF; 2-3 weeks for AVG
maturation.failure_to_mature: Evaluated at 4-6 weeks; fistulogram, intervention if needed

definition.@value: Surgical creation of vascular access for hemodialysis, preferentially native arteriovenous fistula

clinical_pearls: Fistula First: AVF has lowest infection, best patency, lowest mortality
Plan access when GFR <30 - AVF needs 6-12 weeks to mature
Protect veins early - no IVs or blood draws in non-dominant arm in CKD patients
Rule of 6s: mature fistula = 6mm diameter, <6mm depth, >600mL/min flow, 6cm length
